Ode to the monster movie:

 I just saw an outstanding monster movie the other day called [url="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1060277/"]Cloverfield[/url]. It wasnt like Frankenstein or Godzilla or any of the others I can remember from my childhood, and it will very likely change the nature of monster movies to come - a new benchmark - and when it comes out on video in a few months, Ill have more to say about it then. But in the meantime, it reminded me of another great monster film Id seen recently - this weeks movie, THE HOST.

 I was really young when I saw my first monster attacks the city movie. It was [url="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0047034/"]Godzilla[/url] and I was about 8 years old. It was simultaneously thrilling and terrifying. And even though the logic side of my brain told me that it was just make-believe, I would still, for years since, always keep check on the horizon when I was outdoors  because you never know when a prehistoric creature in a rubber suit, created by atomic radiation, might decide to rampage through my town and my parents would probably have to buy a new car and thus wouldnt be able to afford a new bicycle for yours truly  then Id be stuck running beside my friends, trying like hell to keep up, thus getting so tired that Id fall asleep early and thus wouldnt be able to stay up late enough to watch the monster movies, shown on TV late at night. .could happen.

 I cant say for sure why some of us are drawn to such movies. Maybe we have that sort of morbid curiosity that is fascinated by large scale destruction. Maybe we identify with the creature  I want to knock down big buildings! Maybe its the same compulsion that made you want to knock down your little brothers tower of building blocks as you walk by  just because.

 Years ago I watched a movie on TV (It may have been a made for TV movie) called [url="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079573/"]Monstroid[/url].  During the opening credits they flashed the claim Based on actual events.  You might think, So what?  Lots of films are based on true stories.  True enough  but this one was about a giant dinosaur that rises from the sea and terrorizes a coastal fishing village.  Funny that I never read about that in the paper oh wait  maybe I did read about that once in the Weekly World News between the article about how Satan is a space alien and the latest exploits of the Bat Boy.   Lately though, Ive been disappointed with monster movies. For me, Godzilla was the biggest and baddest of them all. The second-rate copies that came after just didnt cut it  like [url="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0055198/"]Mothra[/url], and [url="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0059080/"]Gamera[/url], and [url="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0024216/"]King Kong[/url] (please ignore, for the moment, that fact that King Kong was actually made some 20 years or so before Godzilla  Im trying to make a point here.), but I watched them and loved them just the same.  The problem is that Ive grown up and they hadnt. I hadnt, until now found a film that was as thrilling and scary .and fun as the early classics to a young boy .as I said, until now. THE HOST is such a film. It has the right combination of scary monster, thrilling action, political satire, stress releasing comedy, mayhem, and uplifting heroics as they did when I was a boy. Finally, the monster movie has grown up.

 This film has often been described as Godzilla vs. [url="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0449059/"]Little Miss Sunshine[/url]. This is true to an extent. Its not as much about the monster as it is about the Park family. Three generations of the Park family live together in a trailer on the banks of the Han River in Seoul, South Korea (yes  its Korean  but the subtitles are easy to read and if you dont want to read those, my copy of the DVD had an English-dubbed soundtrack  but gobs are lost in the translation  I recommend you brave through the subtitles .unless youre Korean that is). They are a profoundly dysfunctional family but manage to pull together and support one another when the chips are down. In that way, it is similar to Little Miss Sunshine. The monster isnt humongous, like Godzilla. It cant knock down buildings and terrorize entire populations at the same time  but it is rather creepy nevertheless, and it can certainly terrorize a few dozen people at the same time at any rate.

 THE HOST is funny without being a comedy.  Its scary without being gross and turning your stomach.  Its dramatic without being soppy.  Its a political satire without preaching, and its action packed without seeming unrealistic (except that theres this monster).  Im hoping that this will spur a renewal of interest in making monster movies.  I think it may already have started (reference again to the new film Cloverfield).  I know that if I ever get the chance to make a film, I have lots of monster ideas  but I know that will never happen.  So ..here are my monster movie ideas that will probably never see the light of day.

 

 [list=1][*][b]VORAX: Destroyer of Worlds![/b]  Vorax, the most fearsome creature in the Andromeda Galaxy, travels throughout the galaxy destroying and devouring planets. When he is sucked through a wormhole and reappears in our own solar system, he sets his sights on the Earth. Our doom seems certain, causing panic worldwide  until it is discovered that, due to a miscalculation in scale, Vorax is actually half an inch tall.[*][b]TERROR FROM THE DEEP[/b]  In the future, the ocean is pristine. A century of human efforts have paid off and the ocean is once again clean. A monstrous sea creature, fed up with humans cleaning up his domain, rises up and attacks New York. He lumbers down street after street cleaning up the litter and the trash and the garbage, leaving sparkly clean streets in its wake  and bellowing How do you like it? How do you like it?!!!! Street cleaners and garbage collectors are suddenly out of work, tipping the already teetering unemployment scales into instability. The economy crashes sending the country into a deep depression. Mayhem, destruction, oh the terror, oh the terrorfrom the deep.[*][b]SLUMMO: The Rude Clown!!![/b]  A giant clown-like creature attacks the city making rude gestures and dropping its pants-like garment. Citizens are disgusted and evacuate the city in droves, but SLUMMO has his giant squirting flower-like object waiting for them.[*][b]PLANETRON: The Careful[/b]  Planetron, a giant prehistoric sea serpent, rises up to attack Tokyo  but he doesnt do it all at once. The 300 ft. tall creature first does a walk-through, taking copious notes and occasionally taking out a huge tape measure to check building heights and widths etc. Hell use this data to plan his attack at a later time so that hell know which buildings he is able to knock down for maximum terrifying effect.[*] [b]The Return of PLANETRON[/b]  PLANETRON attacks Tokyo with maximum terrifying effect.[*][b]KLAXON: The Annoying  [/b]Klaxon, a giant space alien, is not very powerful, so it cant really cause any actual damage itself, and it cant really harm anyone directly  BUT  its really really loud and annoying. So much so that eventually the city sustains damage and mayhem as the military knocks down buildings in an effort to chase Klaxon away. Thousands are killed in the stampede to get the hell out of Dodge, much of it due to lack of communication as most people have their ears stuffed with cotton, or stones, or small animals  basically anything they can manage to shove in there just to shut Klaxon the hell up.[*][*][b]THE BEING OF UNKNOWN HORRORS[/b] -  An earthquake opens a fissure releasing a giant creature.  The populace is horrified but it doesnt know why.[*][b]THE NO-NONSENSE BEAST[/b]  A humongous monster attacks an unsuspecting city.  It stomps cars, knocks down buildings, gobbles up people by the boatload.  It withstands every weapon the army and scientists throw at it.  Thats it!  The no-nonsense beast.  Whats the hook, you ask?  An all-orangutan cast.  [*][b]THE MONSTER WHO WAS AFRAID OF OTHER MONSTERS [/b] A large horrible creature, named TELEPHONOPHOBIA, rises from the deep.  It attacks only small towns and suburbs.  Why?  It heard that loads of monsters were attacking the big cities like New   York, Tokyo, London  and he owes most of them money.  Thus he eschews the obvious target cities and turns up in places like Schenectady, Newport News, and Peoria  the big monster in a little pond philosophy.  [*][b]THE MONSTER WHO DIDNT SHOW UP  [/b]A 500 ft prehistoric sea serpent completely fails to rise from the sea, doesnt bother to knock down buildings, totally neglects to terrorize innocent citizens, and generally blows off the chance to rampage through Manhattan  much to the chagrin of city officials who ordered the city to be evacuated and the military to be on hand for just such an occasion  and are now looking pretty foolish  and have sent their aides to look for a Godzilla costume and a camcorder  and step on it if you dont mind.  Oh the horror .the horror.  [/list] THE HOST scores a [url="../m/host/?critic=creamcrop"]94% on the tomatometer[/url].

I haven't seen many monster films, but out of the ones I have seen this is clearly one of the best.  It stands out because it does more than just try to be different from other monster films, but shows the love for the classics while doing its own thing.  Joon-ho Bong mixes satire with a comedic dysfunctional family story with a monster horror.  There were moments when I was torn apart by the scene, other times when I'm laughing at the characters, and sometimes a mixture of both.  One scene that stands out is when the whole family is mourning over the loss of Hyun-seo because she had just gotten eaten by the monster, yet the film slowly turns their mourning into a comedic moment.  Joon-ho Bong knows how to make his audience feel strange.  And I thought that Baumbach was the king of that.  Bong obviously has a distaste for the American government and their foreign policy.  Every single problem happens because of US involvement.  An american man tells the lab assistant to pour the chemicals into the sink, but the assistant tries to warn the American against doing this because it will flow into the river but it doesn't matter.  A few weeks later the little baby monster is found in the river by a couple of fisherman, then a few months later it is seen hanging upside down from a bridge.  The government decides they will intervene and stop the monster, but they believe the monster is carrying a virus that is infecting the people in the city.  Even though Gang-Du is trying to find his daughter, he is captured by the government and put into a hospital with the other "infected" people.  Gang-Du forces his way out of the hospital with his family so they can save Hyun-seo after Gang-Du gets a phone call from her.  No one believes she is alive, but he knows what he heard.  This is where the comedy and tragedy both play.  Gang-Du is kind of an airhead.  He can fall asleep in the most drastic times and he doesn't always make the right decisions. This can be hilarious while at the same time horrible.  When they are running from the monster Gang-Du falls and tries to get back up with Hyun-seo, but realizes he is holding the wrong hand.  He is later made fun of for this.  His family laughs at him for sleeping all the time.  Neither the Korean nor American workers will listen to him.  I felt bad for him.  One of the best family moments comes when Gong-Du's father tries to explain to his siblings how he was trying to fend for himself as a young teenager, but when he failed at stealing food he would get beaten up which caused a problem with his protein.  His father understands that he tries and that his heart is always in the right place.  It's such a beautiful moment, but here are the siblings in the background falling asleep to the story.  I could go on and on about the greatness of The Host, but seriously, it's just one of the best.  

**SPOILERS**

The ending where Gong-Du finds Hyun-seo dead is sad, but it continues with the killing of the monster perfectly.  We want to see it dead not because it's a monster, but because it has destroyed what we cared about so much.  They did it perfectly having the brother throwing Molotov cocktails at it, then miss on the last one when the gasoline is poured, then have the sister who is a world class archer shoot it into his eye.  When it runs I was afraid it would get into the water, but here comes Gang-Du to finish it off by shoving a pole in its mouth and holding it back.  Perfect ending to a perfect film.

The cast was strong (In particular, I especially enjoyed seeing Du-na Bae again after enjoying her in Linda Linda Linda.) and played their parts effectively and compellingly. The soundtrack fit the film well, and the cinematography was great. The monster itself was so well integrated that it felt much more real than the CGI creation it was. The Host draws you in quite a bit overall, it keeps itself from being too heavy and potentially overwhelming through lots of effectively executed humor that set it apart from most films of its kind. The political commentary made is worth noting as well. Ultimately though, as a film, The Host isn't going to blow you away or change how you think about things. It will, however, thoroughly entertain you for its entire run, as it's much fresher and smarter than most films in the genre. I look forward to seeing any and all other works of Korean cinema that make it over here in the future, having consistently enjoyed everything from there I've seen so far. Beats Hollywood cinema any day.

As a creature action film, The Host is quite subdued.  The creature horror, the blood and gore, and terror are all there; however, there is a artistic subtlety to everything.  Although it's pretty much a monster-eat-people-for-no-reason-movie,
the film changes mood enough times to make one question "What is the main conflict here?".  Indeed, the film explores several types of conflict:  monster vs man, man vs man, man vs family, and man vs himself.  The film does justice to each scenario, but overall the different plot lines feel.   disjointed.  Although the human characters may have been given more "character" than this genre is expected to, all the monster movie staples are here.  The  special effects are great.  Second only to Dragon Wars, the film is regarded as on of the best showings of Korean special-effects effort.  There is no quick cuts and edits here.   In a stark contrast to the typical Hollywood treatment, the creature of the film chomps and chews through its victims in clear camera shots: The audience is never cheated of its size or complete shape.  Comic elements are abound, even in the horror scenes.  The film is enjoyable, although be prepared to be bombarded with questions after the credits roll.

Many classify Bong Joon-ho's "The Host" as a monster movie, but that's far too simplistic a label. While a hideous monster does drive the story, Bong balances the thrilling horror plot with social satire and a moving, frequently comical family drama. The CGI work by San Francisco's The Orphanage is top-notch, despite the film's limited budget. While "The Host" sometimes threatens to buckle under the weight of its ambitions, on the whole it's an exhilarating film by a talented and inventive director. Simply put, it's one of the greatest "monster movies" ever made.

There are distinct differences between horror movies and monster movies.  Some monster movies are indeed horror movies, but many are a genre unto themselves.  Movies like Ron Underwood?s Tremors, John Carpenter?s The Thing, and David Croenberg?s The Fly have all told great stories that happened to have large dangerous monsters at their centers.   The genre has been around since early B-movies of the Godzilla vein, but the granddaddy of most modern Monster movies is almost certainly Steven Spielberg?s Jaws.  As everyone (and I mean everyone) already knows, Jaws was effective because of how little of the shark was shown. Most filmmakers studied that film and reused the trick for their own monster movies.  After thirty years of this it?s nice to see a film like The Host that completely ignores this trick and is willing to just show a monster doing its thing.
	The film begins with and American scientist ordering his South Korean assistant to dump large quantities of formaldehyde into the Han River.  Predictably this results in the creation of a mutated amphibian monster the size of a semi-truck.  This creature announces itself to the world when it begins a violent attack at the riverside.  At the riverside during the attack are Park Gang-du (Kang-ho Song) and his daughter Hyun-seo (Ah-sung Ko).  Toward the end of the attack the monster captures Hyun-seo and hides her in his sewer lair for some reason.  The American government reveals that one of their officers present at the river attack had become infected with a virus, as such Park Gang-du, his father (Hie-bong Byeon), his brother (Hae-il Park) and  his sister (Du-na Bae) are all detained and quarantined.  This quirky and often dysfunctional family must work together to escape custody and save Hyun-seo before the monster gets hungry again.
	The monster in The Host is fairly well designed; It looks a bit too venerable but has enough of a menacing presence to make the attack scenes work.  The special effects are pretty good by the standards of non-hollywood cinema, it is clear they were working with a budget here.  The monster doesn?t look like much compared with a Hollywood production, but they?re good enough to not be distracting during the creature scenes.  
	There are a number of political undertones in the script, but it is fairly simple minded and at many times feels like little more than xenophobia.  The United States is blamed for pretty much everything that goes on in the movie: an American dumps the chemicals that create the monster, The United States military is blamed for starting a virus scare, and the United States begins dropping a chemical called ?Agent Yellow? on the city for no apparent reason.  This simple minded Anti-Americanism works to add a sense of intelligence to this potentially mindless script but it hardly stands up to the level of a serious political movie.
	The human characters in The Host are amusing.  The father, Park Gang-du, is a bit of a slacker, and his father works pretty well as a family patriarch.   Gang-du?s sister is an Olympic archer (for reasons that will be very obvious to anyone familiar with this genre) while his brother seems to be a fairly generic badass.  None of these characters are overly complex or even particularly interesting, but they aren?t transparently weak either.  They are humorous enough though, and they provide a good human perspective to the story.  The characters don?t stand out but they are good enough.
	?Good enough? actually applies to most of the movie?s many aspects.  The film tries to be a lot of things; it tries to be a monster movie, a political movie, and a film about a dysfunctional family.  The film succeeds moderately well at all of these things; it?s a jack of all trades and a master of none.  The Host will please fans of the genre and those looking for something different in their sci-fi action, but it will probably not blow anyone away.

It's definitley overachieved with critics, that's for sure. I watched this last night with my somewhat 'just friend' blah blah whatever she is and she fell asleep, and I would've too if I wasn't such a fan of monster movies. For some who might think this review is biased, know this: I live for monster movies. My 'just friend' I mentioned above can vouche for this. I have every Godzilla movie ever made on DVD (some illegal) and I have two pet dinosaur eels named Loche and Champ. Not kidding. But the fact is, this is a movie which is so packed with anti-American messages and stupid humor that it very nearly comes off as a spoof. It really does. There are often times, like in the very beginning, when it is painfully obvious that all director Joon-ho is doing is talking about how stupid and stubborn America is. When the film starts, an American scientist tells his Korean (this is a Korean film, not a Japanese one like some people are suggesting) assisstant to dump the chemical down the drain, but NOT before talking for five minutes about how dangerous it is. America rocks!

The writing is bad. And I'm not talking about the fact that the dubbing is so horrible that it's really hard to pay attention without laughing every five minutes. The monster's coming to be is classic, as in it's a product of chemical runoff, and doesn't waste time trying to explain it scientifically (The Mist did this well). This a good thing. What's a bad thing is when the human characters' actions are so horribly written that it makes it almost painful to watch. There is one scene where two hazmat-like workers stop a truck because one saw a dollar-which was practically invsible-in a sewage drain...on the other side of the truck. Of course, they become monster food. But that's the problem with this script, as in too many of the actions are forced and work only to move along the ridiculous story reminiscent of something from Roger Corman in 1992-oh yeah, Carnosaur. Did I mention this movie is kinda like that?

By the way, before I continue, why is this thing rated R? Just thought I'd ask. Because, honestly, the big F-bomb comes up just once, and I think it's the only cuss word in the whole movie, and there's less gore than on an old episode of Power Rangers.

The story is also painfully silly. Why is it so easy for two guys to sneak into a military base who aren't even wearing military colors? How can a drunk suddenly go all Tom Cruise on some police officers and escape a high-rise building? All these ludicrous subplots seriously detract from the monster itself. In fact, the monster seems like so little of an actual threat that it often takes a back seat to everything else happening.

And this is where I stop totally ripping this movie and talk about the good stuff: the monster itself. The 'Host' is a neat-looking, well thought of, creative, and thoroughly good monster. Its emergence from the river in the beginning is memorable beyond words, and is clearly the best scene in the movie. This monster, unlike ours like King Kong or the Japanese Godzilla, is often much more terrifying. It's quick, it's scary looking, it's brutal, and it doesn't think. It attacks, it kills, and thanks to the special effects of Weta (which worked on King Kong by the way) is simply amazing to look at. When the Host is on screen, this movie is excellent.

[center][b][font=Book Antiqua][size=3]THE HOST[/size][/font][/b][/center]
[left][font=Book Antiqua][size=3]If you're looking for something different and extremely entertaining, please do yourself a favor and watch [i]The Host[/i]. It's a quirky monster movie (yes, quirky) that never failed to entertain and sometimes even amaze me. It's an all-around fun time that works on many levels - as a family melodrama, a comedy, a cautionary tale, and a government cover-up conspiracy - but all these welcome additions to the mix don't take away from the fact that [i]The Host [/i]is just a campy monster movie at heart. The attack scenes with the mutated fish were just flat-out wild, especially the first attack on unsuspecting onlookers. There also were some surprisingly intense moments - [i]The Host [/i]isn't ever truly scary, but the scenes with the children in the sewer were unexpectedly suspenseful. Overall, this was a crazy and original monster flick that I really enjoyed. Two thumbs up for sure. [/size][/font][/left]

A really interesting movie with plenty of twists and turns to hold your interest for two hours or so.  I went in expecting a good old fashioned monster movie.  And for a while, it is.  But fairly early into the movie, Bong forgoes the slow buildup that you normally see in monster movies and just throws the monster right in your face.  After that, the film shifts gears again and starts to venture into satire in which the U.S. and Korean governments practically overshadow all the monster stuff.  The sociopolitical criticism was a bit too broad-ranging and heavy handed for my tastes, but it's still pretty interesting to see its role in a monster movie and how everything develops.  At times, it manages to be pretty dramatically poignant.  And at others, it's really fun and over the top.  Overall, I wouldn't say my life is drastically better for having seen it or anything, but I definitely enjoyed it.  Wouldn't mind checking it out again sometime.

This film was nothing like I was expecting - the title is very misleading. This film is more Godzilla than bodysnatchers.

This Korean offering is a fantastic watch from a cliched start, through a hilarious action-packed middle to an emotional finish.

A doctor at a US Army base orders hundreds of bottles of old formaldahyde into the Han River. Years later, a mutated monster bursts from the shores and attacks the cities people. 

Caught in this is Gang Du, a struggling single father whose daughter is taken by the monster as a result of his mistake during a frenzied escape. The rest of Gang Du's dysfunctional family - his brother, sister and father - are all devastated - spectacularly so. 

In-fighting quickly begins until a frantic mobile phone call from the daughter confirms she is still alive. The family must now break the quarantine and go against authorities to get her back.

The character dynamic of the family is fantastic. There is no love interest here, just the unflinching loyalty of a messed up family fighting for their own. Despite the nobility of this ideal, at the same time the family are completely daft - it's like making the Dingles the heroes of their own monster movie - it's brilliant! 

That's why when you are so easily sucked in to such a likeable rag-tag family, you're gutted for them when things start to go wrong, leading up to a heart-wrenching finale. 

This film ticks all the boxes of a great monster film. Simple story, complex character relationships and good effects. 

The special effects in this film, though not perfect in comparison to the standards that Hollywood has set, are more than adequate. Having said that, it is how and where these CGI graphics are applied that Hollywood took take a few lessons from. 

A must see.

When a bizarre mutant creature emerges from a river in Seoul and kidnaps a young girl, the remaining four members of her family must fight to get her back; but they soon find that the creature is the least of their problems as they struggle with incompetent government officials, cruel scientists and an entire city gripped by panic. Godzilla meets Jaws meets The Crazies in yet another wonderful movie from Bong Joon-ho, director of Memories of Murder and Barking Dogs Never Bite - though this one never quite reaches the heights of those two. Bong uses every cliche in the book and mixes drama, horror and comedy in a typically Asian way - and makes it all work. And, as always, he instills the movie with biting social commentary and genuine sympathy for a gallery of characters (led by the amazing Song Kang-ho from Memories of Murder, The Foul King, etc.).

A minor complaint: The scientists are a tad too pointlessly sadistic, and there's a couple of scenes where the CGI doesn't quite work, but most of the time it is excellent, and the creature is appropriately nasty.

The Parks are a slightly dysfunctional family whose members never quite manage to acheive true success due to an everpresent combination of bad luck and various personality flaws. However, they must pull together and overcome their weaknesses when the baby of the family is abducted by a monster and only they can save her.
 
[center][img]http://images.rottentomatoes.com/images/movie/gallery/1169392/photo_07_hires.jpg[/img]
[i]A 20-something slacker (Kang-Ho Song) is forced to grow up to save his sister (Ah-sung Ko) from a mutant monster in "The Host"[/i]
 [/center]
 
"The Host" is a monster movie that delivers equal amounts of suspense, humor and horror as it unfolds. In this, it is equal to other great monster movies from the original "Godzilla" to "Island of Terror", and through to "Slither". What sets this film apart from other monster movies is the Park family in this movie. The way NONE of them can ever quite manage to rise to whatever challenge is facing them is alternately funny, tragic, sad (sometimes all three at the same time), and so realistic that it gives this movie a totally unique quality. Although families drawing together to fight a monster threatening them--and ultimately triumphing exactly because they have drawn together-- is nothing new, I don't think there's ever been a movie family quite like the Parks before.
 
(Nowhere was the Park family trait of never quite crossing the threshold of success more clearly spelled out when the 7th-grader who the rest of the family is trying to rescue devises a way out of the monster's lair on her own... only to discover that all her work amounts to nothing when her rope made from the clothes of partially digested victims ends up being too short to be useful.)
 
This film is even more impressive because of the way the story resolves itself. The outcome of the climactic battle is in perfect keeping with everything we know about the Parks and their lives, but I still expected I very different ending than what was delivered. 
 
With a good script, excellent special effects, decent acting, and some fantastic moments (the sequence where the monster attacks the crowds in the park along the Han River is one of the best monster attack scenes ever put on film,), the film could have rated a Nine or even Ten if not the way it starts to meander a bit as it closes in on its climax. Basically, the director and screenwriters felt the need to inject a nefarious conspiracy by the United States military into the film--probably so they wanted the International Community to know how kewl they are!--and it served no purpose other than to slow things down and detract from the film's center, the Park family. It's a testament to how strong everything else is that it stays on track and manages to pull together for its climax. (BTW, in fairness, I should mention that a civilian employee of the US military in South Korea DID dump chemicals into the Han River, and the US DID take measures to keep him from being punished under Korean law.)
 
Aside from a single misstep motivated by the director's desire to be invited to cocaine-fueled orgies at Hugo Chavez's presidential palace (or maybe just to get a fan letter from Kim Jong-Ill), "The Host" is a spectacular monster movie with a unique flaire. Every horror fan should check it out, particularly if you enjoyed "Tremors" or "Slither".
 
 
The Host (aka "Gwoemul" and "Monster")
Starring: Kang Ho Song, Hie-bong Byeon, Ah-Sung Ko, Hae-il Park, and Du-na Bae
Director: Joon-ho Bong

I've yet to see a Korean film that hasn't been surprising in some way. This monster movie hasn't changed that trend.

The first thing that really caught my attention was the natural approach to the monster's entrance. It doesn't start with mysterious disappearances or rumors about a creature. In THIS film, people are merely enjoying a day of picnic fun by the river. Suddenly, a few notice there's some sort of creature hanging like a bat from the bridge. They point and stare, debating what it is. Next thing you know, the monster nonchalantly drops into the water, comes to shore, and starts running around like an animal on the hunt.

The last Godzilla remake approached the monster in this fashion. "The  Host" is more fulfilling though because we care more for its characters as they are much more believable than the ones in Godzilla. Their dialog is more natural, their backstories are more in depth, and the drama that ensues between them is more touching.

Now I'm ready for (the tentatively titled) "Cloverfield." Whoo!

Creature features are generally terrible. Usually, the creature is laughable and painfully unscary, the acting is generally over the top, and/or the budget prevents the filmmakers from really experimenting with their monster. Fortunately, the latest creature feature from Korea, The Host, doesn't have any of these problems. Although there is a bit of humor mixed into the movie and a few instances of poor acting and eye rolling moments, the movie was more or less a straight forward, serious people-fighting-monster movie. At the offset of the movie, a young girl is grabbed by the monster and taken into a sewer where the monster takes his prey. However, she lives and calls her father. The rest of the movie basically deals with the father and his family searching for his daughter. The largest problem with this movie is that the creature is shown way too early and far too often. It couldn't have been 10 minutes into the movie when the creature starts to run around the area and mow down anybody in his path. I was hoping for a seriously scary, suspenseful, and tension filled creature feature, but what I got was nothing more than an exercise in showing off how good the creature looked (which admittedly it did). The Host is one of the best creature features I've ever seen, but that's really not saying all that much.

Mr. Host could either represent Iraq or pollution, the metaphor is valid either way. We follow a girl snatched by the creature and the unusually sympathetic family members who team up to save her. A daring resurrection of the Giant Monster Movie which is more complex than meets the initial viewing. What is likely to be dismissed as simply another giant monster flick from the East is actually a complex commentary on current issues, just as the genre's seminal work, Godzilla was. Instead of atomic metaphors, the subject matter is a stew of ecological, political and familial. Broken homes, a mutated fish and fragmented rhetoric all combine to make this a film that, unlike some less informed viewers have stated, a film that ought to be taken seriously. That said, "The Host" is enjoyable for all the reasons a good giant monster movie should be. However, like the poster, which would lead one to believe the monster is a giant squid, there's much more in this film than what's on the surface. Highly recommended.

The Host is kind of a horror movie and kind of a really bad stupid comedy and kind of a family drama and kind of a waste of time.  there's about thirty five minutes of great horror stuff in this bag of candy.  the first twenty minutes were excellent.  then the movie searches for a story to flesh out the horror of the standard chemical dumping in the south korean Han river creates giant monster story.  it would have made a great short film instead of one that stretches to nearly two hours.  i got a lot of design work done during the many parts about a family coping with the loss of a daughter to the beast and the search for her, so in that respect it wasn't a total loss.  but i certainly don't turn to horror films as an excuse to get my work done. that's why i put up with my in-laws for as long as i did.   then there's a whole sideline story of some virus that goes absolutely nowhere and washes away most of the built up terror of the monster part.  then there's some hideously bad comedy that should have been the real horror story.  flat acting performances perpetuate the story like the hunger that drives the beast.  but that first twenty minutes or so was pretty awesome.  too bad they didn't tack it on at the end.  that way when you find yourself saying, "hey, i've seen this stuff before"  your response would have been "yeah but its the best part of the damn film so be thankful they just put it in again." worth a dollar, not much more.  this film will be remade in the united states by a more competent director and the story will be fixed better cause...hey, one thing we do pretty well here in the states is make horror.  just look at the man who runs the country and you'll agree with me there.

Ah, monster movies. This is The Host, and it's probably one of the best movies to come out this year. While the story behind it isn't the most innovative, it's still very entertaining, and I dare a fan of high-octane modern horror/thrillers not to sink their teeth into this. It's two hours long, and feels a lot longer actually, but every second is packed to the brim with excellent, chilling visuals, a healthy, deep sense of adventure, and sprinkled lightly with some loopy midway carnival music at some points for extra effect (the soundtrack is brilliant!). The characters are obviously not the most fleshed out, this being a monster movie, but the acting is generally pretty good, and the characters enjoyable to watch, despite a few sticky moments (the crying scene at the very beginning of the movie was extremely overdone). Directing is very well done; crystal clear and polished, showcasing the best Asian horror has to offer.

I did find it quite interesting how the monster is revealed in the beginning of the movie in it's entirety, not hidden by shadows or water or anything of the sort. I'm no monster movie connoisseur, but in most of the ones I've seen (Jaws, Creep, etc), the monster is usually kept unseen for a good portion of the movie, to build suspense and terror. Not here. "The Host" is openly revealed to the world, without a grand opening of the curtain or a suspenseful unmasking, and while it seems odd at first, the movie is structured to the point where this doesn't matter. It's just an interesting curiosity.

While The Host isn't fully realized in every area (the ending is slightly lacking, and a few characters were definitely not given the proper treatment they needed), and while it's definitely not perfect, it's an extremely entertaining, thrilling, monster movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat for a full 2 hours. Highly recommended.

That's no backhanded slap. This is a Grade A horror flick, done with style, humor and a canny knack not to take itself too seriously. The heroes are a motley family of goofs and misfits, who are both endearing and buffoonish but never unbelievable. The beast, who wastes no time in making himself known once the opening credits are over, is sort of a cross between a prehistoric amphibious armadillo, the creature from The Predator, and a little bit of Dino the Dinosaur with anger-management issues.

The movie is often surprisingly touching and there are scenes that are filled with style and grace, even amidst all the rampaging carnage and Keystone Kops antics, Korean-style. And its ending - on the surface a happy one - also leaves you with a painful sense of loss.

Don't overlook this one even if horror flicks leave you stone cold; it's a modern urban fairly tale gone freakily awry.

This is a fantastic movie. Tons of satire running through a wonderful mix of horror and humor. The movie starts with a campy explaination of the monster's creation, then dives head long into introducing the characters. Then it brings out the monster so perfectly, that you could honestly believe that this is what would happen if a monster ever attacked in real life. The director does a great job of building suspense by showing what's happening around the monster, which makes its fleeting image all the more terrorfying. The couple of time the monster is fully on screen, it is impressive. The best CGI work I've seen to date. My only critique is that when it is on screen, it has occasional moments were it is obviously CGI. I think they should have cut down the amount you could actually see the monster to get more of the "monster under the bed" effect. Besides that, I'm absolutely nuts for this film. A definate buy.

The Host is another one of those creature movies, its quite grotesque and cheesy but it doesnt mean its bad cause its all meant to be that way.

In fact The Host is quite a smart film, it tries to covers lots of themes and subject matters. It manages to critisize the government, the U.S. Army and the paranoia behind the SARS that people lived a few years ago. It carries comments on poverty, grief, family, madness, etc ...

Its funny at times, almost scary on other occasions and its also touching when it has to be. The Host does a lot at once and it surprinsingly works with all the clichés, unexpected turns, interesting plot and depth. It mixes up all genres and its extremely original.

I'm not a monster movie guy. On the grand scale of horror movies, monsters usually hit the bottom rung. Then how is it that the 3 most amazing horror movies of the past year have all been monster films. I speak specifically of Feast,The Descent, and The Host. The Host is an extremely fun movie. It treats its monster extremely realistically as opposed to "what the hell is going on in this wacky world?" People see the monster, are scared, and that's what you need to know. More importantly, however, is the nature of people in times of a crisis. The political atmosphere of this film is thick, blaming unknown diseases and viruses on this creature and using it as an excuse to commit moral atrocities. Yes, The Host is a Korean film and I know that foreign movies (unfortunately) turn people off. At the end of the day, foreign movie naysayers (also known as film heathens) should really just bite the bullet and accept this movie. It's a good time and undeniably a fantastic film.

wow. just wow.

as far as monster thrillers go, this movie firmly stands side by side with films such as jurassic park.

not often do i find myself curling into my thick wool blanket, eyes wide open at the screen, filled with excitement.  not over scary movies, anyways,

can it be called a scary movie, though? sure. although the movie put me through the gamut (sp) of emotions any good movie will.  fear, joy (from satire), heartache, anger, frustration...

the movie will have you screaming "run, dammit!" and "save her, for the love of God!" and "go! go! go!" to the kidnapped's loved ones.... and why? because you love them too.  the family is so endearing in this film.  this poor family with the most rotten luck in the world... proving that the strength of family can overcome the darkest nightmares.

 if you watch and listen closely, you can see all the subtle messages about how to live life... how to love family... there are a number of shots at the Korean and US governments and their underhanded methods to "protect" us. i love it.

and so i watched all the extras. the director put in EVERY little deleted scene. that was cool.

but there was one extra titled "Bong Joon-ho's Reflections."  I thought, okay, he's gonna talk about all those hidden messages.  or at least the origin of the story? or maybe the actors and what a great job they did. but nope... instead, he spent 10 minutes APOLOGIZING to individual actors... even calling out extras by name... when they didn't get screen time or they faces weren't visible.  i've never seen a whole section of a dvd dedicated to apologizing.  he even apologized to the bicyclists of the Wonhyo bridge whose "leisure time was interrupted." haha. Mr. Joon-ho is a class act, through and through.  With this film alone, one of my new favorite directors. cheers!

[b][size=4]'Gwoemul' ('The Host')[/size][/b]
[i]Bong Joon-ho, 2006[/i]

[img]http://i235.photobucket.com/albums/ee162/jedimoonshyne4/4-8.jpg[/img]

Many people (myself included) have made much about the purity of Asian cinema. Specifically, the lack of influence upon it by the movie-pop-culture of the Western World. As fulfilling as it is to mention this point, one can never forget that within film, Hollywood influences everything. Such is and was the reach of said institute, it has inspired and captivated many. This by no means excludes Asian filmmakers however original they may be. One case in particular is South Korean writer/director Bong Joon-ho who received critical acclaim and worldwide exposure for his 2003 effort '[b]Memories of Murder[/b]'. A film that reinvents the serial police thriller genre that was rife in American cinema throughout the eighties and early nineties. Next up for Bong Joon-ho was the monster-movie genus, something particularly prevalent in both American and Asian cinematic history.

[img]http://i235.photobucket.com/albums/ee162/jedimoonshyne4/3-8.jpg[/img]

Since hitting Western shores, '[b]The Host[/b]' has been compared to many films, a fact perhaps unavoidable considering the director's outlook. One such comparison has been drawn between itself and Steven Spielberg's iconic '[b]Jaws[/b]' - a film that explores the catastrophic consequences of a monster created by Mother nature herself. Bong Joon-ho has gone a distinctly different route however, focusing upon the slightly less mysterious yet altogether more perilous idea of a man-made monster. A subject that brings with it all kinds of issues; pollution and politics to name but two. '[b]The Host[/b]' follows a bumbling father Gang-du (played by the much-loved Song Kang-ho), who is drifting through a life of incompetence when the unthinkable occurs. A horrifyingly beastly product of the local toxic-laden river begins terrorising a nation known for its flappability. Director Joon-ho plays on this well, throwing out political swipes aimed at the widespread panic induced by the (very real) SARS epidemic not long ago. Using Gang-du as the innocent figure caught up in this mess.

[img]http://i235.photobucket.com/albums/ee162/jedimoonshyne4/2-7.jpg[/img]

Just as with the crime-thriller genre, Joon-ho does an excellent job respecting yet differentiating from the well-trodden generic path. Creating a film that is a lot more conscious of the message it presents. On the outside, '[b]The Host[/b]' is an exciting and suspense-fuelled blockbuster, action dripping from its pores. Yet inside the film is itching to make a point, and to do so with a well-practiced smirk and occasional wink. Each member of the family-cast is well aware of the subtle humour that the film offers up, and as is such with Asian wit - they perform with straight faces throughout despite the plot's sporadic hilarity. As a film that defines itself using the work of others, '[b]The Host[/b]' is an incredibely original feat. One that takes a tongue-in-cheek stance, proving to be as infectious as it is barefaced.

Asia has a long pedigree when it comes to big angry monsters emerging from the sea and devouring its populace, which is why The Host gets into the action pretty quickly. There's no dicking about by incredulous authorities putting the rampaging beast's excesses down to an escaped weather balloon or bad light. No, the guys in the hazmat suits know their Godzilla's from their graf zeppelins. Or maybe the heavy pollution in the Han river meant everyone was grudgingly expecting a genetically quadro-spazzed mudskipper to leap from the waters and go on a killing spree with the same inevitability as the next san andreas quake. While the film straddles an uneasy line between the very tragic and the fairly funny, the acting (particularly the daughter and the grand father) is superb, as are the dynamics between the family members. There's also a bit of politico-historic commentary aimed at the U.S.(Agent Yellow, anyone?).
It's more funny than scary and includes some interesting social commentary. I was disappointed by the ending, but then again I only saw half the movie...so take this all with a grain of salt.

"The Host" was a great fusion of genres. Bong Joon-ho was able to successfully blend the horror creature feature genre, with comedy, making this one of the funniest horror comedies I've ever seen. When the Han River gets polluted, an amphibian becomes mutated into a flesh-eating monster three times the size of an elephant, but with the agility of a Russell Terrier. This creature kidnaps Hyun-seo, the youngest of the dysfunctional Park family, the rest of the family defy the stay of emergency and the government authorities to search the sewers for her. This film works on so many levels, apart from being a comedy and horror, this film is also a political statement against the Unites States for the bombastic way of handling the bird flu 'epidemic' a few years prior. So the Park family trudge through the sewers and in their own way, fighting to rescue to save Hyun-seo, who was the only one who brings them together as a family in the first place. This film is charming, tension-filled and hilarious. Get infested by "the Host", you'll enjoy this one.

Bong Joon-ho demonstrates his considerable talents once again in his modern take on the monster movie. Boasting a stellar cast of some of the greatest actors working in Korea today, The Host tells the tale of a dysfunctional family who comes together when a mutant beast emerges from the Han river, scoops up young Hyun-seo (Ko Ah-sung) and disappears. It features all the thrills and chills you'd expect from a creature feature, but also something more-- a real emotional center, found in the Park family. There is commentary, as well, but it is almost certainly unintentional-- this story is about a family's struggle more than anything else, and for it's unique perspective on this genre alone, it is worth seeing.

[color=green][size=3][font=Arial][i]The Host[/i] is an unusual, but somehow always entertaining monster movie out of Korea. Its not the usual brand of monster horror that American audiences are used to seeing. Director Joon-Ho Bong ([i]Memories of Murder[/i]) attempts to combine a number of different genres into one nice little, two hour package, but the film is so busy at trying to do a number of things, and to a lesser extent it succeeds. [i]The Host[/i] is one part family melodrama, one part scary, edge-of-your-seat thriller, and one part government cover-up conspiracy.[/font][/size][/color]

[font=Arial][size=3][color=green]The plot isnt complex, and the set-up is simple: toxic chemicals are illegally dumped into Seouls Han River from a U.S. military base, which results into creating a mutated, angry and equally hungry creature. The film doesnt make us wait around till the final act to get a good look at this beast (it shows up within the first twenty minutes, in the middle of broad daylight, no less), with what is maybe the best part of the filmits opening, which nicely sets the stage of just another typical average day where something very unusual is about to happen. When the monster first appears theres literally no suspense or building up to its appearance; its simply just [i]there[/i]. As fast as lightning, this toxic and hungry feeding machine is out of the water, on to land, and chomping away on innocent civilians.[/color][/size][/font]

[font=Arial][size=3][color=green]When Hyun-seo (Ko Ah-sung), the young daughter of Gand-du (Song Kang-ho), a local, but lazy snack vendor, is kidnapped by the creature and taken back to its sewer lair (shot mostly in real sewer locales, not sets) to serve as a midnight snack. Feeling completely miserable, and responsible for letting her get snatched away by the big beast, Gand-du unites with the rest of his whole family; his father, sister and brother, a really crew of misfits if there every was one, to work together to rescue her from the clutches of the beast.[/color][/size][/font]

[font=Arial][size=3][color=green]Theres only one problem: the government has begun rounding up survivors who may have come into contact with the monster, and are setting up quarantine, fearing that the monster might be carrying and playing host to a deadly virus.[/color][/size][/font]

[font=Arial][size=3][color=green]Of course theres no real proof to suggest that any virus actually exists, but its the government and whatever the government says, must be true, right? Yes, layered within this goofy monster feature is a social commentary on the governments abuse of misinformation. Does it work? Surprisingly, it does. The publics paranoia about the virus strangely, but appropriately echoes of the SARS or Avian Bird Flu epidemic.[/color][/size][/font]

[font=Arial][size=3][color=green]Like George A. Romero before him, director Joon-Ho Bong takes what is simply just another monster movie and gives us not one monster, but two. The first being the nasty beast the leaps out of the Han River, and the other being the governments ruthless and completely asinine approach to dealing with the problem.[/color][/size][/font]

[font=Arial][size=3][color=green]While the film does have its charms, and works from moment to moment, [i]The Host[/i] doesnt quite equal the sum of all its parts. The overall tone of the film is a bit spastic; constantly changing gears quickly from suspense to goofy humor, but what makes up for it is how the film is surprisingly unpredictable, and defies the majority of genre conventions and clichés, and in doing so, [i]The Host[/i] takes on a wild and crazy life of its own. If youre a fan of monster movies, this ones worth checking out.[/color][/size][/font]

Director Joon-ho wastes no time in designing a thick, meaningful layer of hilarity and humanity into his protagonists, then quickly sicks the creature (which resembles a seriously stretched mix of an overlarge tadpole and Brazillian Piranha Fish, causing it's rough and undefined features to look oddly sinister) upon them and bystanders with little to no warning. The film then delves into themes littered with political, economic, familial and psychological taboo as the plot advances (at a fine pace) towards the film's admirably anti-cliche climax. This is a film assembled after ages of monster movies, from "Jaws" to "Tremors," "The Host" recalls all our childhood fears and favorites, weaving them together into a fantastic homage and clever movie.

Why was this movie so good? I'm still wondering about that...
I did not think that it was a good "monster movie". There was no suspense, the CGI was very questionable, but that didn't bother me. Was it scary? Not even a bit. Is it funny? Not exactly... So why is it so damn good? Simple: It's fun. The utterly dysfunctional characters bring life to this otherwise dull plot outline, and the colorful way the film was made made every scene very enjoyable. Unlike some American movies I've seen lately, this movie achieves humor without trying to hard (*cough* Scary Movie 4 *cough*). It's very mild thrills come at you sidewise, in a much different way than most horror movies. Moreover, the film presses down on all the keys of one's emotion. I laughed, I groaned, I cried (well...), I cheered, and I got rather mad on occasion. 
What makes "The Host" special in my mind is how it is different from other movies that are out there. Everything from the characters to the way it provokes the feelings it provokes, is unexpected. Even the cinematography doesn't conform to how most movies are shot, and succeeds in making a very original movie. If I were to describe just a handful, I would double the length of my already fairly long review. That being said, I suggest that you watch it instead. And for those fellow Asian-Americans, you will be able to experience another side of the humor of this movie: If you fluently understand Asian humor, this movie is Caddyshack. I also suggest that you watch it in it's original Korean. Subtitles arn't that bad, and even the characters voices are important. Just...just...watch the movie.

"The Host" starting making some pretty big waves at film festivals all across the world before finding its way stateside. With a unique blend of dark humor, creature horror, and suspense, this film tells the tale of a creature that comes out of the Han River in Korea and terrorizes the population. After a young girl gets captured by the beast, her family vows to get her back and destroy the creature. I highly reccomend it for those looking for something different and who enjoy a good horror comedy.

For a film dubbed a hybrid of Jaws, Jurassic Park and Tremors one's expectations were justifyably astromical... to compare the host with three pioneers of their respective genre is simply ludacrous. The film isn't as witty as tremors, frightening as jaws nor as epic as Jurassic Park. There seems to be a growing trend when an import from the far east reaches these shores. this trend being automatic critical acclaim, which on occasion is unjustified and completely unfounded (Audition and Battle Royale 2 come to mind).  The Host continues this notion as the acclaim plastered all over the DVD case is so far from hitting the nail on the head, it creams the poor guys thumb holding that proverbial nail. Put simply, the film isn't that good. I haven't got anything against Korean cinema, Chan-Wook Park's "Vengeance" trilogy is a masterpiece but I just can't help but think if this film was American, it would have got slated (I know the film is a political swipe at America itself but that excluded, it would've got slated). The supposed comedy elements drag on for far too long and the opportunity for some truly terrifying moments is repeatedly missed. It never really knows what it is, it's not dead pan enough to be a comedy, not scary enough to be billed as horror and the monster isn't iconic enough to a 'Godzilla' like monster film. I found myself nervously laughing at certain moments and despite it throwing you straight into the mayhem from the get go, the action is few and far between for the remainder, which is a little disappointing.  I was expecting so much from this film, instead I feel I did not just watch the film the I was promised, another victim of hype.

The Host continues to hold up well nearly a decade later, and it's another testament to Bong Joon-ho's skills as a director and storyteller. Yes, the CG is as terrible now as it was then, but it's not as prevalent as you remember and becomes a non-factor. That's because the monster movie is genuinely exciting and has some good less-is-more action sequences, yet it's the other touches that continually stick out - the well developed character dynamics, offbeat humor and socio-political commentary. It's a well-rounded package that culminates in an emotional finale, the effectiveness of which I had forgotten about, showing why The Host remains one of the best monster stories of the 2000s.

'The Host' takes all pre-conceived monster movie clichés and throws them out. This here is a film that doesn't conform to American standards. For one thing: the characters are characters, not just monster fodder. Another: the monster/story ratio is about 1:3 as opposed to the traditional 3:1. Gone is the usual 'what does it look like?' suspense that is a trademark of a stateside flick; this beastie is presented in the open in broad daylight.

Anyway, the plot itself is as simple as it gets and the creature has only the most basic explanation. The struggles that the characters face are actually NOT from the monster, but from the government that is trying to control them due to a suspected virus contamination. Whether this is an intentional play on the whole SARS thing is debatable. but I think so.

Oh, it's full of funny dark-humor as well.

I think many people take this film WAY too seriously.  First, it sets out to make fun of its monster movie predecessors, particularly the American ones.  Secondly, it is a social commentary on the Big Brother relationship between the United States and Korea, the tensions between generations/social classes, and the ramifications wrought from a divided nation dependent on "Big Brother".  The actions of the characters were necessarily exaggerated in order to lighten the intensity of the issues addressed and  to make fun of its own cultural eccentricities.

That aside, it stands out amongst most horror fare today because it manages to scare you without relying on building suspense to ultimately have something jump out at you (though it has a few of those moments).  A lot of the fear comes from the film's ability to make you feel the fear that one should feel when witnessing a monster run through your city, unlike other films where the sight of a monster is ineffective until it kills someone.  Even scarier is the way the film's protagonist, Gang-du, is treated by the government as a result of his attempts to find his daughter, in addition to the way the government deals with the chemical outbreak that created the monster in the first place.
The great story is coupled with a high production value, as director Bong Joon-ho creates fluid moments combined with solid visual effects that bring the hideous creature to life.  Filled with several frightening moments, and a few comedic ones, "The Host" is a solid monster film that has that depth of character that hasn't been seen since the likes of Alien or Jaws.

I know this movie seems like a bad War of the Worlds spoof at first, but it's actually a very clever satire about America's corrupt political policies toward Korean citizens in the 1960s. Basically, what the U.S. government did at the time was dump this radioactive shit in Korea's Han River because America "didn't know where else to put it." Obviously, that stupid decision killed thousands, and the monster that comes out of the river symbolizes the contamination of both the river and America's foreign policy. Excellent, thoughtful movie!

Political satire and monster movie shenanigans mix in this funny/scary Korean blend. A wriggling fish beast, concocted from a military incident, begins harvesting humans from its comfortable spot on the Han River. An inept father loses his daughter to the creature and sets out with his family to get her back. Of course, the government takes over as the monster is apparently the host of a deadly virus, creating a national security threat. Those monster scenes are the best in the flick as the CGI is not only convincing, the realistic photography of it make its attacks that much more thrilling. The social commentary is blatantly anti- American (though any government disruption of civil liberties can be a bad thing), but its the family drama that propels the action, offering a romp of mayhem that is unusual in its premise, but unusually enjoyable.

As such, it offers up comedy.  But it also serves up elements of a political thriller, as well as slices of the horror and action movie genres.  The cinematography is terrific, and the acting is fine.  All the elements work individually, but they only loosely mesh.  Some holes glare in the plot as well, but overall "The Host" is entertaining and creative down to the last scene.

A father and his extended family are reunited when the monster captures his daughter, however things become complicated when the government quarantines them, believing they have contracted a virus from the monster. It's definitely worth seeing, but do yourself a favor and avoid the dubbed audio track. It's better with the Korean dialogue and subtitles.

But before I get into that, might as well get this out of the way - this movie has a fantastic aesthetic and plot, and works as an absolutely great monster movie. That is probably because it focuses on the story of a father trying to find his daughter after the monster snatched her rather than just "Ahh!  A bit monster is attacking the city! Help!" Though it gets a bit confusing at times, usually it works very well and even manages to be pretty creepy sometimes.  So here's the big problem - it's dubbed.  Now maybe if you speak Korean and you're watching the original, you can't complain about this.  And i doubt i would either.  And maybe there's an undubbed American version with subtitles(which is what I wanted to see).  I'm hoping there is one, but the one I know exists is the one I saw.  A great monster movie that was HORRIBLY dubbed in english.  Honestly, the voice overs are just about as terrible as you can get and make the movie so funny and pathetic-sounding at some of the most interesting parts that it completely destroys whatever the movie has going for it.  Are you eventually able to ignore it?  Not really.  But I suppose it's tolerable by the end... still, it's hard to take the movie seriously when all the actors are voiced over with overly-enthusiastic bad english actors that clearly don't have the best dialogue to work with either.  When they first see the monster the dialogue is along the lines of "What is that?  What is that on the bridge?  It's swimming nearby!  I wonder what it could be!  What do you think it could be?"  Take dialogue like that, add bad actors and crap in a cup.  Then you have The Host's voice overs.  Listen guys, I don't mind subtitles... but if you must... if you MUST dub it... jeez, get some talent.  Great movie.  As long as the bad english actors don't bother you too much, I'm sure you'll enjoy it a lot.  Definitely worth seeing.

Gue-Mool/The Host is a B-grade Korean creature feature. Although it is basically a straightforward horror flick, and not amazingly good, it's not of the so-bad-it's-funny variety. If it's funny it's because it's half a comedy, but the other half is actually a suspenseful, reasonable sophisticated horror. In that way it's a bit of a hybrid. It's Korean and if the Koreans do anything well in horror, it's the quiet, suspenseful moment in which you can almost smell the fear, the moment becomes icy and taut and epic. This is what I love about Korean horrors, even if you can generally walk through the holes in the plot.

One of the best films I've seen in a really long time. It was funny, horrifying, and heroic.

It makes you feel like "Oh this movie is going to be silly" but then something bad happens and you get the "Oh fuck, are they serious?" feeling. I think that is a brilliant way to do things. It gives you different emotions and feelings throughout the film which create a horror/comedy/paranoia/adventure atmosphere. Most movies now days just want to pick one of those elements and shove it down your throat. There is a chemistry, and The Host does a perfect job. 

The rest of this review is going to turn into spoilers, so beware.

My favorite part of the film has to be the ending. I just loved it how everyone seems to just start dying and that there isn't going to be any hope in the movie. It was just poetic how they all worked together and fought the beast off. It had a kind of existential ending with the daughter dying, but a little hope for the man who lost her with having a new son in his life. He wasn't going to go on in life having a void, he had a replacement. That sounds horrible that he lost his daughter, but his daughter was the hero in the film. She led them to the beast and helped save the boy. 

I think the only problem I had with the film was the beast itself. It just had the whole B-Movie animation to it. I think if this film had a bigger budget that it would be probably one of the best (sci fi? Horror? I'd say more Sci-Fi, but whatev)  to have been released.

Disregard my previous review of this movie.  This movie FUCKING rules and it does reach its full potential.  I've been re-watching a lot of movies lately and I find that I, usually, enjoy it more the second time than the first time.  I guess knowing what's going to happen, I look for the little details of the movie and the subtleties and nuances.  This movie is no different, I enjoyed it SO much more than I did the first time.  I don't think my rating will change, but this movie is really an excellent monster film.  On the DVD cover it says it's on par with Jaws.  And as much as I love this movie, I'll have to disagree with that, because is usually more suspenseful because you don't get to see the shark until, near, the end of the movie.  So when you see the shark for the first time, it's much more impressive because they found a way to turn a negative (the shark was originally supposed to be seen from the beginning, but the mechanical shark malfunctioned during the shoot, so the shark was mostly hinted at or you could just see the fin) into a positive.  So in that regards, Jaws is a much better film since in this film you get to see the monster from the very beginning.  It's not necessarily a negative at all, but it can't be compared to Jaws at all.  Plus this movie is actually much more than just a monster movie.  It's sort of a hybrid of Little Miss Sunshine (which came out that same year), Finding Nemo (at least the part of the father searching far and wide for his daughter, in this movie) and social commentary.  This movie succeeds in taking the monster genre and making it believable.  The problem with monster movies is that most of the times they're just corny and campy.  Godzilla is just camp entertainment, and for the people that like that sort of thing it's great, but this movie really tries to not take the route of the usual monster movie.  In most monster flicks, you usually don't care for the characters.  Take Cloverfield for example, I couldn't get into the characters of that movie because the cast pretty much just got cast because of their looks.  I understand that you wanna make the movie pleasing to the eye, but don't sacrifice the characters for that.  The cast of Cloverfield were basically just models and how is the audience (who probably AREN'T models) supposed to relate to these assclowns.  In this movie, you have normal people with normal jobs trying to find the little girl that was taken by the monster.  It's a simple story and it pays of tremendously.  Also one of the things that Cloverfield failed at was making you feel like the monster was a threat at ALL  times.  I can understand that New York is a big place and that the monster won't always, conveniently, be where the main characters are, but the movie loses focus of that and at the end of the movie you're like "oh yea this is a monster film...I forgot"  In this movie, the presence of the monster is ALWAYS apparent, the monster isn't always attacking the people of South Korea, but you KNOW he (or she for all I know) is there.  They do this by cutting back to where the monster keeps  the girl (and eventually the little boy).  So the monster's presence is always apparent.  Another thing I liked was how at the end, when the monster is finally defeated, you feel that the main characters actually accomplished something by killing it.  It's something that's not been apparent in monster movies in forever.  That's what it needs to feel like, like they accomplished something and that they finally eliminated the threat.  Which brings me to the sequel (with a different director and different cast, most probably), how in THE HELL are you going to make a sequel and have it not be just about the corniest and most contrived bullshit ever.  You'd think that after the events of this movie, that the government of Korea would be more CAREFUL about how they handle toxic chemicals.  I just can't wrap my head around that, this movie doesn't NEED a sequel. The monster is dead,  there's no logical room for a sequel there.  What are you going to do???  Drop more chemicals in the river????  Again, won't the Korean government (in the movie...DUH) be more careful of how they handle toxic chemicals after this.  If it was the same director and cast, then I'd give it a chance, but I have absolutely NO hope for the sequel and it'll probably be camp entertainment like Godzilla and that pisses me off.  And don't even get me STARTED on the fucking American remake.  Christ almighty get your own ideas for FUCK'S SAKE!!!!  GODDAMNIT!!!!  FUCKITALL!!!  Anyway, the cast of this movie is so great.  They all very distinctive personalities and are likeable in their own way.  Song Kang-ho is so awesome, though.  I can't stress enough how great Song is.  I'll never get old of saying this, but he's one of the best and most diverse actors around.  He's just as great at comedy as he is at drama.  He's one of the best at that, because not every great dramatic actor can do comedy (IE: Edward Norton) and not every great comedic actor can do drama (and I mean consistently...Adam Sandler and Eddie Murphy have only done a couple, and not very consistently at that and Jim Carrey doesn't count cause his comedic style is hit and miss for me, same thing with Robin Williams).  So that makes Song's diversity as an actor all the more impressive, because he can really convey a whole set of emotions just by his facial expression.  Look at this movie (when he first appears at least) and look at Thirst, two completely different versions of the same actor, but he's still excellent in both roles.  Song is just incredible and he's great here.  But in reality, the cast is really great in this movie, especially the girl who gives a really good performance despite it being a very challenging role for someone that age.  With that said, this movie is excellent, probably the best monster movie of the past decade, which isn't saying much.  But that says more about the quality of other monster flicks, than it does about The Host.

I have to admit, part of me is torn on The Host.  I enjoyed it, but with all the hype I was expecting it to end up being more than it was.  The creature was interesting, (though I can't help but picture one of the mounts from the old Golden Axe arcade game whenever I see it.  The purple one that attacked by thrashing its tail.), and although the events that led to its creation seemed awfully far-fetched, it turns out that scene was based on an actual event that took place.  Of course, no mutant monsters resulted from the real thing, but it just goes to show that truth can indeed be stranger than fiction sometimes.  And despite the gripes I have, (see below) the film still had good pacing, coupled with enough tension and inventiveness to keep your interest.

*SPOILER WARNING*
Now for the parts that bugged me.  There were a lot of loose ends that were never tied up.  The whole "virus" sub-plot alone was rendered both confusing and pointless to a degree, when it was determined there likely wasn't any virus at all.  (Yet they still drilled into the hero's head, looking for it?!  And on that note, since there was no virus, what was there to explain the hero's utter resistance to the anaesthetic he was injected with?)  And there was strong evidence against there being a virus, long before they started using that "agent yellow" gas against the creature (and the protesters gathered nearby). I understand that last bit was probably a historical commentary of sorts, political/student demonstrations and all that, but it seemed a clumsy way to go about it.  It felt forced.  And speaking of the gas, why were some people dropping over dead from breathing it, while others (namely: the main characters) seemed largely unaffected?  ESPECIALLY since the gas was supposed to "eliminate all biologicals" within its radius?  There were other things that irked me a bit, but they were minor in comparison.

Yet even all of that wasn't enough to override the fact that this is still a very enjoyable movie at its core.  It's just not quite the amazing, revolutionary flick that some people have been calling it.

The Host
2006, 120mins, 15
Director: Joon-ho-Bong
Cast includes: Kang-ho-Song, Ah-sung-Ko, Du-na-Bae, Hie-bong Byeon, Hae-il Park

The Host was released in the UK several months ago, and despite recieving a set of positive reviews (a blessing rarely bestowed upon it's genre) it couldn't get bums in seats at the multiplexes. The creators won't mind, the film did huge buisness in native Korea and the UK makes up a small fraction of money made, but it feels weird that an intelligent and equally fun monster-mash can't compete with sluggish blockbusters like [i]X-Men 3[/i] and [i]Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest [/i]in the Western Box-Office. Hell even the tiresome wrestling farce [i]Nacho Libre[/i] made more money in the same year.
The fact it's foreign and has the Friday night crowds biggest fear (Subtitles!!! Run for the hills!!!) probably account for some of the film's financial failure but really that only goes to show what a narrow minded world we live in.
The story isn't any more complex than normal blockbusting fare (indeed compared to the Pirates movies it's like an 80's DTV action flick) but it has alot more in the way of depth than most of it's kind. Based around a family of five, the plot consists of the group attempting to retrieve a member stolen away from them by a giant mutated creature that has been spawned due to the dumping of dangerous chemicals. Really in a nutshell that's it, the plot thickens and the english title does become quite apt, but overall thats the most you have to get your head around.
The creatures past is somewhat vague and the filmmakers present the simplest explanations and conclusions but overall it shouldn't bother the audience much, and is made even more forgiving by the fact we have for the most part a solid set of 3-D characters. Kang-ho-song is brilliant as the lazy and underachieving father, who due to a mistake on his own part see's his daughter taken by the giant menace. He convey's a real sense of redemption and made for a sympathetic lead. The support is also superior in quality, the highlight actually being young Ah-sung-Ko who plays the unfortunate family member. Her time in the monster's domain is heartfelt and engages the audience on every level. If her role hadn't been played as well as Ah-sung-Ko does, the film would have been significantly weaker. The rest of the family aren't as unique but manage to develop a decent set of characters, and the chemistry is often wonderful between the clan.
The creature himself can't rival Hollywood effects but at times he does look damned good. A little to cartoon like to scare but the way he disposes of his victims and the build-up to several attack sequences more than compensate. Indeed when the monster first rears his slimey head about 15 minutes in, it's for a wonderfully shot and breathtaking attack scene. I have debated in my head if this is a good thing or not (the movie never tops this section) but at the time everyone I watched it with had their eyes glued to the screen.
The comedy elements in The Host don't gel as well as one might expect. The humour usually slapstick occasionaly comes from nowhere and interrupts an otherwise powerful or suspenseful scene. Some of the writing is well done, but overall the film is awkward in it's presentation of jokes and light hearted moments.
The Host isn't perfect, at around two hours it does feel to long, and in the middle section the pacing slows and does the movie no favours. Still the beggining is for the most part great and the end sequence provides plenty of adrenaline and excitement, along with a surprisingly morose and depressing finish.
There are clear political undertones in The Host and for the most part director Joon-ho-Bong handles them well. I expect these themes will fly over the heads of the usual blockbuster viewers, but I and several others that I know really appreciated them. I guess the biggest compliment I can pay The Host is that is respects the audience, something that fewer and fewer films do these days. Indeed it can be taken on surface level as just another action movie, but those who choose to look at the picture this way are missing out as the movie also comes with some good performances, likeable characters and a message at it's heart. Now that's entertainment.
