Here's a thought: stop reading this review right now.  That's right, you heard me.  Don't read ANY more.  Critics have simultaneously built up and destroyed chances of this Korean monster film ever finding a mainstream American audience.  A pity, really.  Believe me when I say that "The Host" is an acquired taste-- certainly NOT living up to expectations like unto traditional, B-grade shlock fests.  There's practically no build up to the creature's reveal, very little reliance on special effects, a predominence of acting (i.e. character drama over thrills), and an unbelievably overbearing political undercurrent, particularly in the film's latter half, as one of our sympathetic characters is subjected to a series of invasive scientific "tests" at the behest of the American government.  The conclusion is a stark contrast to early comedic moments, especially considering the material.  Cheesy one-liners are not to be found anywhere, and our heroes are far from plucky and endearing.  Face it, this is a hard film to swallow considering the story: a strange mutated fish creature manages to kidnap several unsuspecting victims, carrying them to his lair to feed.  Yeah, sounds cheap.  Believe me.  But it's worth the two hours.

[center]As un-serious as this movie appears to be, it takes some serious effort to discern what the filmmakers were actually attempting to do. I dont want to misinterpret this box-office destroying epic of the East, but Im also not going to lie when I say that something was definitely lost in the translation. Is it a satire? Thats my best guess, but all the critics are calling it a freak-out monster-flick. Let me tell you, I laughed more than cringed, was more disappointed than engrossed, and still dont understand the intentions of the creators. But I can make one thing pleadingly clear; The Host has nothing on Jaws[/center]
[center] [/center]

[center]Near the tourist-cluttered shores of a Korean river, an unconventional clan of snack-bar workers reside. Toward the sewers and beneath the bridge naps a monster; always helps customer demand. Park Gang Du (Kang-ho Song), father of the interestingly more mature Park Hyun-seo (Ah-Sung Ko), mans the riverside junk-food emporium during the afternoon, on any normal day. But to his sleepy, indifferent surprise, a slick, blood curdling, fish-like, dragon-being (See how hard this thing is to describe) emerges from the water; a mutated creation of dumped chemicals from a nearby laboratory. Now, when the youngest is taken, Park Gang Du and the rest of his family fight through governmental extermination, a few character flaws, oh, and not to mention, the enormous, flesh-eating, Godzilla-knockoff to get her back alive. [/center]
[center] [/center]

[center]Critics thrive upon films such as The Host. Films that dont stick to a mold, that tatter boundaries and set restrictions. They feel obligated, or really just content with praising a film, such as this one, because its so distinctive. The Host is an intelligent film, I cant deny it that compliment, due not only to the political implications it makes against SARS and government regulation but also because of its handle on the monster-movie, which they so readily and steadily parody.[/center]
[center] [/center]

[center][url="http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/host/gallery.php?page=4&size=lores&nopop=1"][img]http://images.rottentomatoes.com/images/movie/gallery/1169392/photo_05.jpg[/img][/url][/center]
[center] [/center]

[center]The movie does have its segments of success as a frightener, the opening rampage being the most visionary and staggering, but even this sequence has noticeable flaws. Unlike Jaws or other closely categorized films, The Host unveils its antagonist too quickly. The filmmakers seem rushed, intent on showboating their CG marvel without any needed buildup. Its almost laughable how the monster abruptly makes his debut, and the film would have been better off creating a climax where we see it fully, first hiding it in corners or in the shadows where we begin drowning in anticipation.[/center]
[center] [/center]

[center]Comedy is also something that The Host plays with unsparingly, allowing jokes to pour into dramatic scenes where the audience is in limbo over whether to bust out laughing or not to. In truth, the performances are quirky enough to make some of the gags work, but only in the beginning. By the end, it just becomes irritating and distracting from the terror-undertow. Still, the conclusion is touching, the effects used advantageously, and its one hell of an entertaining picture. Smart in a sense, with its satiric know-how and willingness to be something different, but all these layers just dont mesh. The Host just ends up disorienting, a mess of ideas that could have been assembled in a much more effective way[/center]

This was actually one of the first monster movies that I've seen from Asia, other than the ever-so-popular Godzilla, Gamera, and the few other monster movies of the past.

The story as a whole is pretty interesting, but it did leave quite a few unanswered questions. Actually, leaving some of these questions to the viewer's imagination may have been a good thing. The movie actually starts out with a bang. At around the 15 minute mark the monster, in its entirety, is already wreaking havoc. You actually end up feeling sorry for the main characters at this point as well. Ingenious. This movie also does have a pretty good and emotional ending. Where this movie lacked in my opinion was the hour in the middle. It moved really slow and it dragged at times with the monster only making short appearances for seconds at a time. Oh, in case you are wondering, this movie isn't that gory or scary at all, so if you're in the mood for those things stay away from this film.

The acting is pretty good. Kang-ho Song flourishes emotionally with his character while Hae-il Park does a nice job as well. The few English speaking actors were pretty lame though. It felt like they were just reading right off the script.

This is probably the element of the film that most people will want to know about. The CG. Well, the monster is actually done pretty well and only looks really fake at only a few parts. You also get some nice cinematography at times the monster is on screen, allowing you to actually get a good grasp of the creature, unlike other films that give you only quick glimpses until the end of the film.

Overall this movie is above average, but it wasn't anything really spectacular. If you rank it upon monster movies it will most likely be in the upper half as well. Definitely better than others like The Relic, Mimic, or the American Godzilla.

Realism isn't a necessity for a great monster movie.  At least, I didn't think it was until I saw this Korean import.  And while a huge river-mutant isn't exactly realistic, this movie feels so grounded... the characters so mundane... the action so bound by physics and logic, that it all just clicks.  And by the time the fractured family unites for their final stand-off, you can't help but cheer.
The computer generated beast isn't the most realistic movie monster ever concocted, but it is one of the most believable.  It lumbers and slithers and lurks like an actual wild animal.  And it doesn't pop up out of nowhere for fake scares.  I love how the film lets you see it coming from a hundred yards off.  By the time it's on top of the victim, you've had sufficient time to be scared silly, not just startled by a jolt of loud music.
Along with the frights, there are some unexpected moments of humor and real emotional depth.  I've heard that the English dub is terrible and ruins the tone of the movie, so you should definitely go with the subtitles.  (Although I'm not quite sure why the people actually speaking English sounded so weirdly stilted.)
On the whole, "The Host" was a nice surprise and a very well-made film in a genre that rarely impresses.

The social commentary about how agencies deceive the public and about how we should take better care of our earth are pounded home with alittle too much emphasis. The Host is an interesting little moster flick. On the one hand it was an entertaining if trashy no-brainer of a film, with plot holes, bad science and a predictable finale. However, on the other hand, take any other film of this genre, from any country, and see how The Host compares. Name one other monster movie where you actually start to care whether the characters live or die, let alone remember their names. Aside from King Kong I'm sure you're drawing ablank, much as I did. What sets The Host apart is not just its pleasant (if stereotypically Korean) use of colour and sound, but the fact that the focus of the film is not the monster itself, but how its trail of destruction affects the lives of a single family, how they band together in the face of adversity, and how they seem to be unaffected by US-designed biological weapons. Erm...

The Host has left me in a sort of no-man's-land of opinion; on the one hand it seems ridiculous and underwhelming, on the other sits a decent monster flick laced with black comedy and horror. No matter what though, the between-the-lines polemic is apt and topical. First, the Americans (still with a large military presence in S Korea) are given short shrift, not only as the latent architects of the tragedy, but also as the gung-ho interventionists. Secondly, the creature seems to stand as a metaphor for growing pollution of waterways (in this case the Han river in Seoul). However it's taken, the film does feature some impressive shots on location - even managing to make the monochrome urban grey and infinite, soulless bridges look alive.

One of the better modern monster movies out there you can have the pleasure of discovering.  The Host is about a mutated monster that forms in the Han River after it gets seriously polluted.  It rampages the riverside, snacking on the local civilians.  It snatches one little girl up and brings her back to its lair, and this movie is about her family coming together and trying to reunite with their little girl.  This movie has lots going for it.  It's really a movie that transcends genres; it's part horror, part comedy, part monster movie, part disaster movie, part family dramaâ¦ and they're all effective.  It's well directed and is all together a delightfully slimy package.  It isn't terribly subtle with its anti-American environmental policy message, but it was never something that bothered me.  I also think they did a good job with the monster; even though it's obviously CGI, I thought they used it as effectively as possible.  It's a big juju bag mix of a lot of different ingredients, but the result is something well worth your time, and it is the highest grossing film in South Korean history for a reason.

[left][font=Courier New]The monster flick, a genre of film that is easily mishandled. I can think of many movies involving giant creatures that dont amount to any bit of entertainment value at all. Then again, there are a decent amount of these movies that are able to knock your socks off. Joon-ho Bongs [i]The Host[/i] doesnt knock my socks off per se, but the film is one of the most entertaining monster flicks to come around in ages.

Bongs creature, as it emerges from Seouls Han River, is a feast for the eyes. This is one of the most unusual creations in horror film history. But amazingly the creature doesnt take on too much of a life of its own. While [i]The Host[/i] is a monster movie, the monster doesnt end up being the only thing worth watching in the film. Still, the film knows how to perfectly use this monster and is able to create some great thrills along the way.

The Park family that the film revolves around gives the dysfunctional family motif some new charm. I like that the film has characters such as Gang-du (Song Kang-ho) being among the films heroes. While most American monster flicks have some fresh faced young actor playing the hero, it is nice to seem a frumpy everyday kind of guy take the helm. Plus you have some other great characters in this family. I especially liked Nam-Joo (Du-na Bae), a female archery medallist. And Gang-Dus daughter Hyun-seo (Ah-Sung Ko), who offers up a really great performance as a girl trapped in the monsters den.

There are two problems I had with [i]The Host[/i]. The first being the humor. Yes the movie is funny when it needs to be, and this humor succeeds marvelously. But the film still has its moments where the humor seems out of place. Such as the moment where the family is mourning Hyun-seos capture by the monster. I know that people react differently with a lose in their family, but their reaction was ridiculous and over the top. I also had a problem with how the creature at times would come off as an awe-inspiring creation rather than a menacing one. Seeing it do its acrobatics felt awkward in this film. 

Other than that, [i]The Host[/i] is one of the biggest surprises Ive had this year. It is a fun film with a lot of thrills and chills. The movie might not register well with some viewers, and I completely understand that. But for those who are looking for a good monster flick, which [i]The Host[/i] essentially is, give this film a viewing.[/font]
[/left]

[size=3][color=red]Before watching this Korean film titled The Host, I was expecting the following things: A scary monster, some good comic relief, and an entirely new idea on the monster movies. Well, I did get a couple of these things, yet, when the movie ended, I felt strangely unsatisfied. The film had substance to it that every monster movie shoud have, however, there was just something different about it. Was it the monster? The action? Or, maybe it was because there contained a family dramatic tension to it as we contemplated the strange plot.[/color][/size]
[size=3][color=#ff0000][/color][/size] 

[size=3][color=red]The story centers on the dysfunctional Park family, who is introduced to us in dire poverty as they run a small snack joint next to Han River. Park Hee - Bong, an elderly man around his 60's, not only runs the place, but also lives with his entire family. His oldest son, Gang - Du, is a lazy, forgetful, even childish character who is unemployed and whose wife left him. Nam - il, the youngest son, is a drunk with a foul - mouth and has it hard getting a job. Nam - joo, the only daughter, is possibly Hee - Bong's pride and joy, as she applies in sport competitions as a first rate archer. There peace is destroyed one ordinary day, as a monster (a cross between a lizard and a fish) splashes out from the river and starts crunching down on innocent tourists as they run desparately. For the Park family, their youngest member and daughter of Gang - Du, a teenage girl called Hyun - seo, gets snatched by the creature and dragged into the sewers. The government tells witnesses of the tragedy that it was caused by a virus, in which "the host" is infact a primary cause of the creature. But, of course, we as the audience know that the origin was brought on by two scientists shown in the beginning, dumping a dangerous chemical (phenaldehyde) into the sink, which leads to the Han River. [/color][/size][size=3][color=#ff0000]As the entire country of Korea is in panic over the so called "virus", the Parks family take matters into their own hands and try to save Hyun - seo when they find out that she is still alive. [/color][/size]
 
[size=3][color=red]The monster is created out of standard CGI effects and makes Godzilla look like a loveable toy. As the creature spits out the excess of bones that it can't swallow, I was very much reminded of a lizard. Since Godzilla was nothing but a giant amphibian mutated by radiation from a nuclear explosion, The Host's monster is also a giant animal mutated by a science mistake. More importantly, this creature feature is actually scary, not just on its structure, but by the way it creeps up on its victims.[/color][/size]

[size=3][color=#ff0000]If your expecting a giant blockbuster action packed movie, The Host is not it. Its script acts more like a family drama, then it does as a B sci - fi flick. Which is not saying that makes it bad, just different. There is actual thought that goes into the development of each character, including the monster, as they coexist with the bizarre plot. In a nutshell, The Host is creepy, slimy, disgusting, funny, and just plain strange. I had a great time watching it, and hope that America can take a few pointers from it.[/color][/size]

The Host is a brilliant movie. I feel that it's one of those movies  that for once in a while can actually be considered unique, not because its plot is altogether unique, but because of the fusion of different thematic elements. There are moments in this movie that are hysterical, while there are other moments that are beautiful and deep as a dysfunctionl family learns to deal with death and loss. It also contains many moments of suspense and horror as you witness this monster wreaking havoc on poeple. The acting is superb; the cinematography is beautiful and artistic; the plot and layers of political satire are interesting. This movie is just so good because it has so many layers. You can't label it just a monster/horror movie. But even if you don't want to delve deeper into the meaning of the movie, you are able to appreciate it at a surface level.

This movie's okay for what it is, but I have to say, it's also a disappointment. Joon-ho Bong, the great Korean director, has been much better and this is in fact my least favourite of all his films. 
The concept is great, formaldehyde pollution causes a fish to mutate over the years into a huge, vicious sea monster type thing that one day jumps from the water and begins terrorizing the residents of a city. A girl is snatched by the monster, the family tries to track her down, all the while the city is trying to control the situation in their own clueless and unhelpful way. 
I guess what doesn't work for me here is the characters. They are most of the time way over the top and are an example of the main thing that doesn't work, which is that Joon-ho Bong doesn't seem to know whether he wants to make a cheesy B-movie or a higher quality monster flick. This indecision makes the B-movie scenes bring down the higher quality ones and the higher quality ones feel out of place to the B-movie ones. 

The Host has its moments for sure, the first time the monster comes ashore and starts creating havoc is the movie's greatest scene and and a damn fine and effective scene in its own right. 
But more often than not it just doesn't strike the right note and, for me anyway, Bong's greatest success thus far, is his weakest film.

I bow to no man in my admiration of contemporary Korean cinema -- the most imaginative and disturbing national cinema in the world today -- but this one just didn't really distance itself enough from run-of-the-mill monster movies to warrant the fuss it has kicked up among critics who usually know better (Anthony Lane???)

Definitely not your average horror film, especially under Hollywood standards. This hit from South Korea turned mega domestically in 2006, becoming the highest grossing Korean film in cinematic history that year. The film was seen 13 million times at theatres, in a country with a population just over 49 million. Demographically speaking, just how did they do it!? Well first off, you need to write a politically motivated horror film based on events still fresh in memory. Then you spice it up with some unconventional comedy and drama, hire recognizable actors, throw in about 10 million dollars worth of CGI and voi-la! Movie-ala-profit. Of course, the actual budget of 11 million dollars is very moderate under international standards so one can only assume that a lot of careful planning went into this film. The experience however, seemed very spontaneous and fresh, and it was a lot of fun while it lasted. The political part of it is the semi-anti-American nature of the story; an irresponsible American causes problem, many Koreans suffer, then the Americans overkill resolution. The filmmakers were careful enough to kick their own government as well for their lack of intervention so overall it was justifiable, but the depiction of the U.S. government is still unfavorable nonetheless. How ever that may be, the fun part was watching the family search for their youngest, Hyun-Seo (played by talented little miss Ko Ah-Seong), who is taken by a giant land-crawling mutant fish and held captive in its lair. They believe she is still alive, despite the insistence of authorities who think otherwise, and attempt to hunt down the beast themselves. We're talking a working class family here and not trained hunters, so when the hunt is on a series of seemingly random events occur, you will laugh, get confused, but laugh anyway. At least by the end, all of that eventually lead to a semi-happy ending. Thematically, the film matches that of the early Godzilla films, but what they do better is the realism that went into the creature's physical characteristics. CGI is CGI, but considering the budget they did one hell of a good job. Sure gave me nightmares. . . I saw the thing in a trailer months before I saw the feature film and still I got nightmares, twice. It's so freaky-lookin', broad daylight won't ease the terror.

[color=white][i]The Host[/i] is a strange film, strange in what it is about, strange in the way it approaches the material, strange in the way the story unfolds and in how the characters develop. It is a monster movie, but far from a conventional one: It is mostly about a dysfunctional family and how the appearance of carnivorous sea creatures disrupts their daily routine. It is a horror film, a comedy, a social satire and a family drama all at once; sometimes the synthesis works, sometimes it doesn'[/color][color=white]t, but [i]The Host[/i] is always interesting.[/color]
 
[color=white]The film opens with a scientist pouring a large amount of formaldehyde down the drain in his lab. The chemicals seep into a South Korean river and have spawned giant amphibious monsters that eat people whole. We meet Gang-du (Kang-ho Song), a dim-witted man who runs a snack hut with his elderly father (Hie-bong Byeon) and his young daughter Hyun-seo (Ah-sung Ko). They live on the river where those nasty creatures reside and one of them makes away with Hyun-seo. Panic erupts as the government attempts to quarantine anyone who has encountered one of the monsters. Our protagonists escape from the clutches of the evil doctors who want to run tests on them and recede into the sewers of Korea to find Hyun-seo, who is still alive in one of the monster's nests.[/color]
 
[color=white]All of this unfolds at a brisk paceit is exciting, suspenseful and entertaining, and it recalls classic monster movies like [i]Creature from the Black Lagoon[/i] and [i]Jaws.[/i] But the flow of the film is interrupted by several strange episodes. For example, when Gang-du and his family are mourning the disappearance of Hyun-seo, they become so emotionally distraught that they fall into a heap on the floor and clamor and climb atop one another. Is this intended to be funny? If anything, it's awkwardly staged and positioned. Later, Gang-du is captured by the men in biohazard jumpsuits and is given a lobotomy. It's a grim scene, but later Gang-du seems to have been completely unaffected by the treatment.[/color]
 
[color=white]Maybe I'm nitpicking. [i]The Host[/i] is the highest-grossing movie in Korea's history, and it's receiving glowing reviews abroad. As a creature feature, it works marvelously: The special effects are great, the action sequences competently edited and shot, and the characters are surprisingly well-developed. But the movie simply has too much on its plate: As a comedy it's not that funny, as satire it's erratic, and as a drama it's often too bleak (the ending, for instance, is a total downer). I'm giving the film a mild recommendation, thoughdespite its occasional atonality, it is unique and amusing.[/color]

While this is one of the best creature features I've seen in some time, its flaws are distracting enough to lower the level of enjoyment I thought I'd feel throughout. There's an entire subplot involving this non-existent disease that seems to have been included solely to account for why not enough is being done by authorities to subdue the film's monster. It's more irritating than plot-advancing, and for me, it dumbed down the story. There are also certain aspects of humor in Asian cinema that I guess I just don't get, however I won't go into that here. When the movie becomes a quest to seek out and destroy the creature after it kidnaps the daughter of a main charcter, the form becomes a type of quasi-"Jaws" homage that would have worked beautifully had it not been for certain distractive elements. 
The monster in question is like the love child of Godzilla and the plant beast from "Little Shop of Horrors." And props to the filmmakers for having the guts to reveal the entire creature fairly early without wasting any of the suspense. Finally, a modern horror picture that doesn't tease or insult the viewer's intelligence by serving up the same old shadowy, almost-glimpses of the villain until midway through the show. "The Host" is sprinkled with other all-too-common, by-the-numbers cliches, but the film itself feels original enough that it can get away with them.

Ah-sung Ko plays the young Hyun-seo with such maturity, she really makes the picture work, and she's only fifteen!
Kang-ho Song as Gang-Du is at first pathetic and comical and then brilliantly heroic! 
The action is expertly unleashed, if not slightly rushed, and the special effects are damn good. 
It was awesome and DEFINITELY worth seeing. So many American monster movies want to be this good, but none measure up to this one. 
See it!

Though this film from Korea, might be a jumbled mess of genres and ideas... there's something about it that works... and it works damn well.  The first twenty minutes left me clenching my seat, it begins with excitement and then slows down for a bit.  The thing about "The Host" though, is that even when the monster isn't on screen, its still fascinating.  The characters are interesting and the dynamic of this family allows the audience to care for them, we get to see enough of them to connect with them on a personal level.  There's also this bizarre twisted humor laced in between the action and drama, and it certainly doesn't fall flat... this movie is actually quite hilarious.  The special effects might be extremely mediocre, but its believable enough... and thats all that matters.  The performers all overract at the beginning, but they slowly calm down and give in admirable performances.  The political underlinings, the tense and edge-of-your-seat action sequences, the poignant messages of family, and characters that stick with you, make this crazy-ass monster movie something of a memorable event.

[b]Concensus: [/b]Surprisingly mixes its genres well, its funny, suspenseful, and emotionally resonant... while the special effects are mediocre, this is still a must-see monster movie!

In Seoul, South Korea an American scientist (Scott Wilson) spots dust on his jars of formaldehyde. It is ?dirty? according to him, so he orders his Korean assistant (Kim Hak-sun) to dump the hundreds of canisters down the drain. The assistant informs him that it is a toxic chemical, and the contents will eventually arrive in and contaminate the Han River, but the boss sticks to his orders, and the assistant follows them (this was based on actual events). Two years later, a beast has grown, and has commenced an assault on the shore of the river. Park Gang-du and his father Park Hie-bong run a tiny little nothing of a snack stand at this location. When his daughter is kidnapped by the monster, the rest of the family returns to mourn the tragedy. Together, they must put their discrepancies aside, and find a way to save Hyun-seo. For the first thirty minutes, "The Host" is dazzling in a way few motion pictures of its kind have achieved since 1993's "Jurassic Park." Indeed, the initial setup of the premise plays with a tried-and-true archetype?that of the spilling of dangerous chemicals by way of a tyrannical American. The Host is a subtle critic of American foreign and domestic policy in the form of a monster movie.  An American scientist orders his Korean employee to dispose of at least 50 bottles of formaldahyde into the river Han.  The toxic chemicals end up creating a mutated amphibious fish creature that is roughly the size of a large bus that goes on a killing spree one nice afternoon eating dozens of picknickers.  In the process, the youngest member of a family is stolen away by the monster.  The rest of the movie is about this family attempting to get her back.

The movie seems to be more than just a monster movie.  The Americans have created, through their irresponsibility, a monster enemy that terrorizes Korea.  But, to make matters worse, the American government then declares that the monster is the carrier of a deadly virus, and order various biochemical agents dropped on it, as well as quarantine everyone who had been in close proximity to the monster.  We eventually learn the Americans have made this part up, and that there is no virus.  The critique seems to be that America has created its own enemies, and now rather than fight that enemy head on, uses the existence of the enemy to create a phantom enemy through propaganda. 

But the movie is mainly a monster movie, and as a monster movie, it has its pluses and minuses.  The monster is shown running along the river, in broad daylight, towards a crowd of people, knocking them aside and eating them as he runs.  That was fairly terrible in its own way.  And the few times we see the monster, it is interesting.  But most of the movie is devoted to the family, their agony, their mission to rescue the youngest daughter/niece/granddaughter, and how the mission transforms them from selfish, bumbling misfits, to courageous heroes.  So why didn't I like the movie?  I didn't like the movie because it seemed too slow in places where it should've picked up the pace, and I never found the story of the monster all that exciting to begin with.  The political commentary was interesting, and original, and fit with the Asian monster movie tradition of using the monster as a metaphor for global fear (Godzilla, for instance is traditionally believed to be a collective response to Japanese worries and concerns about nuclear power and Hiroshima).  But I nonetheless found myself bored 1/3 to 1/2 the time.  Maybe under different circumstances, I would've liked it, but my first viewing, I found it boring.

The great thing about this movie is that it isn't your typical "Jaws," "Godzilla," or any other monster movie that I have ever seen.  It has a political and moral message woven into it.  I'm probably going to watch it again soon, because I am positive there was some stuff that went over my head that I just didn't catch.  You know what, the more I type, the more messages I think about that Bong Joon-ho brought up in this one movie: dysfunctional family values, environmental issues, political issues (both American , as well as Korean.), and I am sure there are others.  Long story short, if you can get past the culture differences (sometimes outrageous acting), this movie is an amazing piece of artwork.

I guess I just enjoy virulent anti-Americanism in my movies, between "The Host," which gets away with its utterly justifiable moralizing, and "Severance" (which doesn't). "The Host" isn't a platform showcasing buffoonery versus arrogance versus pure evil; instead, the Iraq War allegory is styled around the giant ant/spider/gila monster/random beast b-movies from the fifties that were their own comically ineffectual allegories. If you're unlucky enough to remember Roland Emmerich's misbegotten "Godzilla Takes New York" remake -- it's like that, only acutely aware of its being a total gourmet cheeseball and embraces it enthusiastically, as if the MST3K folks were making their dream movie to sit through.

The monster movie has made it into the 21st century--and almost in one piece!  Though something is lost between this and more venerable monster classics (the obvious comparison being Gojira) I found The Host to, overall, satisfy my post-modern-monster craving for the time being.  It did compromise itself at moments in order to try and keep the widest possible swath of audience fully engaged (silly moments were added which we could've done without) it pulled together in the end to deliver, as its ancestor did in 1954, a scathing indictment of contemporary politics.  The fact that such a message can be disseminated by a gigantic mutant killer tadpole is one of the saving points of modern cinema.  Encore!

The most intriguing thing about The Host is that it actually works best when the monster is not on screen.  The characters are wonderfully written, and we find ourselves identifying them with easily during their quest.  The Host also works as a political satire, if you choose to view it in such a way (the politics aren't very veiled).  However, whenever the pesky monster comes into play, things begin to drag or just  grow plain cheesy, since there isn't really that much of an explanation for its existence in the first place, beyond a stock b-movie plot.  It's unfortunate that the film doesn't work in the area it primarily inhabits, since there is a really great dark comedy buried somewhere between the blood and slime.  Kudos must be given for the unconventional ending and cinematography.
